title: Past Detroit Mercy athlete convinced suicidal man not to jump, to be honored
text:
Past Detroit Mercy athlete helped convince suicidal man not to jump Abby Campbell, now a Detroit Police Officer, will be honored Friday before Detroit Mercy's men's basketball game. Lodge earlier this year. Elaine Cromie/Detroit Free Press (Photo: Elaine Cromie, Detroit Free Press) Buy Photo CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
With a man’s life hanging in the balance, Abby Campbell felt her chest throb. 
Thump, thump, thump. 
“My heart sank,” said Campbell, whose maiden name is McCollum. “You have to forget that you’re wearing a (police) uniform and remember that you’re just a normal person.” 
Campbell, a Detroit police officer from the 12th Precinct, was faced with a life-or-death situation during the morning of Feb. 4, when a suicidal man, standing on a freeway overpass at Livernois, threatened to jump down onto the Lodge (M-10). 
Campbell, a Monroe High School alumna and former University of Detroit Mercy soccer standout who helped save the man’s life, will be honored by the college before its men’s basketball game against the University of Illinois at Chicago at 7 p.m. Friday at Calihan Hall. 
Detroit Mercy is dedicating the night to all first responders and members of the military, offering them free admission to the game. Campbell, after being recognized, is expected to hand the game ball to Titans coach Bacari Alexander. 
“It’s a proud moment,” Campbell said this week. “I work for the greatest (police) department in the country, and went to the greatest school in the country. I’m forever in debt to them both.” 
Campbell and her partner, police Cpl. Robert Nill, a field training officer, arrived at the freeway overpass in Detroit around 7:30 a.m. to assist the primary unit, officers Eric Brown and Sean Bell. 
With Detroit police, firefighters and Michigan State Police at the scene, the unidentified 51-year-old man stood on the overpass ledge, staring down at passing cars on the freeway. 
That’s when the 24-year-old Campbell, who joined the police department last April, stepped into action. 
“First, I asked him, ‘What’s going on in your life?’ I tried to understand where he was coming from,” Campbell said. “He didn’t want to talk much. He kept saying that he was dizzy from watching the traffic.” 
Campbell continued dialogue with the man. 
“I told him to turn around and grab the fence so he wouldn’t lose his balance,” she said. “He was like, ‘Nobody cares about me. I don’t want to be here anymore. I just want to die.’” 
Campbell was not deterred. Buy Photo 
Detroit Police Officer Abby Campbell, 24, poses for a portrait on Monday, Feb. 13, 2017 at the intersection of Livernois Ave. and John C. Lodge in Detroit. Officer Campbell is being awarded by her alma mater before the men's basketball game for First Responders' Night this Friday, Feb. 17, for helping talk a man down from jumping onto the John C. Lodge earlier this year. Elaine Cromie/Detroit Free Press (Photo: Elaine Cromie, Detroit Free Press) 
“I said, ‘There are so many people here that care about your life. We wouldn’t be here if we didn’t,’” she told the man. “I said, ‘You have a lot to live for. This isn’t going to happen. I’m not going to let it happen.' ” 
After nearly an hour, the man came down from the ledge. He was taken to Detroit Receiving Hospital Crisis Center for treatment. 
“She (Campbell) has displayed the type of leadership and valor which has become synonymous with the Detroit Police Department,” read a statement on the department’s Facebook page. “Her actions, and that of her fellow officers, resulted in a man’s life being saved.” 
Campbell's path to service was rooted at an early age. Her father, Charles McCollum, was a pastor, and her mother, Becky McCollum, long had served as an infant teacher at Meadow Montessori School in Monroe. Campbell initially planned to become a social worker, but shifted gears before earning a bachelor's degree in criminal justice and master's degree in intelligence analysis at Detroit Mercy. 
“I never wanted a 9-5 job where you sit at a desk,” Campbell said. “To sit at a desk really isn’t my forte. ... I like being on the streets and helping people. For them to ask for your help is an honor. At the end of the day, we’re all human beings and come from the same cloth. 
“I grew up in a household where you were taught to treat others how you want to be treated. My father would give the shirt off his back for anybody and expect nothing in return. My parents made me into the person I am today.” 
Campbell, a soccer forward, scored 17 goals and had 14 assists while playing for Detroit Mercy from 2010-13. She had five game-winning goals before serving as a graduate assistant coach and earning her master's. 
Detroit Mercy soccer coach Mike Lupenec wasn’t surprised to learn of Campbell’s heroics. Campbell played 68 games for the Titans and was named All-Horizon League Second Team as a junior. She also played lacrosse as a college freshman, and joined the basketball and softball teams as a senior. 
“She was always a very positive young lady, on and off the field,” Lupenec said. “She’s a great role model, and we’re proud of everything she does. We have kids in our program that look up to her. Everything she does in life, she works hard.” 
Campbell, who credits Detroit Mercy for preparing her for life after college, feels blessed to be a police officer. 
“People come to Detroit because this is the best police department in the country. The Detroit Police Department is the gold standard,” she said. “I love Detroit because I’m a Titan. My heart is here and I’m fortunate to have a job here.” CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE
